executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency.

Over the past five years, public transportation services have faced significant fluctuations. The COVID-19 pandemic brought unprecedented challenges, severely reducing ridership as lockdowns and business closures curtailed daily commuting. Government intervention played a critical role in maintaining and revitalizing public transit. The Biden administration's Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, signed in 2021, earmarked $1.0 trillion for infrastructure and transportation initiatives over the next decade. Increased federal funding in 2023 helped offset previous declines in economic performance, which cut state budgets and pressured public transport. As the economy recovered, higher disposable income led some commuters to choose premium transport options like Uber and Lyft, particularly in cities with ride-sharing restrictions. Revenue has been declining by a CAGR of 2.5% over the past five years, and is expected to decrease by 2.0%, reaching $83.3 billion in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Federal Funding and Expansion Programs Help Offset Low Economic Performance
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Elevated crime levels in major cities like New York and Philadelphia remain a concern, prompting increased security measures to protect commuters and enhance public confidence in public transit. Consequently, profit for public transportation is expected to remain stagnant.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Awareness of Greenhouse Gas Emissions Encourages Ridership and Fleet Upgrades
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The green movement raises consumers' awareness of the environmental effects of vehicle emissions, pushing them toward more eco-friendly choices, like public transportation. Public transportation leaves a cleaner imprint on the environment because it reduces the number of cars on the road.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Elevated Government Investment in Hybrid and All-Electric Buses
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Elevated government investment in hybrid and all-electric buses hastens the green transition by reducing fleet emissions. Public transportation organizations are using the environmental movement as a marketing tactic to get people to switch from driving cars to taking the subway and buses.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Elevated Crime Levels in Big Cities Deter Some Consumers From Using Public Transport
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Skyrocketing crime levels in the New York City subway system have pushed Eric Adams to deploy an additional 1,000 police officers at the start of the year to protect commuters and enforce fares. Random stop-and-searches on people entering the subway system accompany the deployment of law enforcement officers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Contractionary Monetary Policy Will Threaten Public Transportation
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Elevated interest rates amid stubborn inflation will pressure the expansion of public transportation. Tighter credit conditions and the US government's skyrocketing treasury yields imply that funding will likely have to moderate because of elevated borrowing costs and the US's sky-high debt level.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Urban Population and Cost-Aware Consumers Brighten the Outlook for Public Transportation
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: US roadways are already hampered by traffic, and travel times will climb as the population in major cities continues to rise. Many cities are limited in their ability to expand highway systems because of a lack of available space. Providing an efficient and affordable public transportation system offers a solution to congestion issues.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Policymakers Will Increasingly Seek Ways to Reduce Carbon Footprint
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Public transportation will continue to be an anchor of the green movement. Transporting the masses in single vehicles and transitioning to hybrids and low-emission cars will significantly reduce emissions.

According to the most recent data from the US Department of Transportation, in 2022, there were 1,873 electric buses on the roads in the US, comprising 3.0% of total buses in use. The lack of infrastructure emphasizes the need for further investment in charging networks to support the transition and make it feasible for the future.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Congestion Pricing Tax Will Increase Funding for Public Transportation in New York City
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The congestion pricing tax to be imposed in NYC on June 30th will charge drivers $15 to enter Manhattan, while the cost for trucks will range from $24 to $36, depending on the size of the vehicle. The plan is to alleviate congestion in the city and promote higher utilization of public transport.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Public Transportation Will Benefit From Government Infrastructure Investment
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), also called the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, dedicates $1.2 trillion to upgrading national infrastructure – including $550.0 billion above the baseline investment. Nearly $746.0 billion in IIJA funding is still to be announced as of June 2024, indicating remaining capital influx opportunities for the Public Transportation industry.

industry_definition: Public transportation agencies primarily operate regional passenger transportation systems with regular routes and fixed schedules. The industry does not include taxis and limousines (IBISWorld report 48533), charter buses (48522) or school and employee buses (48541).
key_trends: The public transportation industry has a low level of competition.
Government subsidies incentivize public transport operators and prevent competition between service providers.
The industry encounters external competition from different types of road transport. These include automobiles, taxi services, ride-share services, private bus operators and limousine services.
COVID-19 caused public transport revenue to cascade. The economic and health crisis required extensive federal aid to prop up the industry, which is an integral part of the overall economy.
People migrating to urban regions elevates demand for public transportation. Congestion in metropolitan areas is driving further investment into public transport to meet growing commuter demand.

New York City's congestion pricing tax benefits public transport. With the increased costs of owning a vehicle in the NYC area, more people will resort to using the subway or bus network for their daily commute.

Skyrocketing crime in the subway system leads to an increased presence of law enforcement in major cities. To address residents' safety concerns, law enforcement agencies have increased patrols and security measures in public transportation hubs.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Passengers under 25 are usually students and young adults without high disposable income. Public transportation is the best way to commute, particularly in a city, because it's affordable and doesn't require a driver's license.

With an emphasis on convenience, this group is more likely to use public transportation modes incorporating mobile ticketing or real-time tracking, like ride-sharing and bike-sharing services. Most people in this age group are students, implying that they depend on their families to transport them around or live on college campuses where commuting isn't required.

People aged between 35 and 44 comprise a large portion of the workforce. As such, they also make up a meaningful portion of daily commuters as they rely on public transportation to commute to and from work. An extensive percentage of this demographic lives in urban areas, making mass transit increasingly popular.

People in this age group have families and are at the height of their careers. Consequently, they may prefer the reliability of public transportation, especially for commuting to work or visiting friends and family. If their careers and family lives are demanding, public transportation alleviates the stress of owning and caring for a personal vehicle.

Older adults, especially those with mobility issues, are more likely to rely on public transportation to reach their destinations. To capture demand from adults over 55, public transportation companies should implement accessibility features, including elevators, wheelchair ramps and dedicated seats for people with disabilities.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Federal, state and local governments are essential sources of public transit funding because taxes and grants primarily subsidize most operations. The government also provides funding for expansion programs and capital works projects designed to improve the safety, accessibility and reliability of public transit services. Consequently, government funding is an essential determinant of industry revenue and growth trends.

business_locations.location_description: Major US cities and other densely populated metropolitan areas are the leading providers of public transportation services. Older, more established transit networks are more common here.

Cities also tend to have greater public transit systems, as these areas have a cultural tradition of public transit use. Much of the working population of the New York City metropolitan area uses public transportation to get to work or school. The densely populated region makes it unfeasible to depend on personal vehicles for transport in key cities because of the need for more parking and overall road congestion. The NE region contains Boston and Bridgeport, CT, two densely populated areas with large working classes, making public transportation essential. Boston is considered a pioneer in the public transportation industry because it was the first US city to establish a subway system. The public transportation network is extremely well-developed in urban areas such as Boston, Hartford and Providence. In rural areas of the New England region, the public transportation sector is more limited, but there is still demand for transportation services, particularly from elderly and disabled individuals.

Public transportation thrives in tourist destinations and college-oriented cities where people have limited access to personal vehicles. Its affordability and ease of use make it the primary mode of transport for visitors. The West boasts extensive public transportation networks because of abundant tourist destinations and colleges. Facilitating commutes via public transport entices tourists and makes the city a more attractive destination for visitors.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FTA regulates the handling of accidents and hazardous conditions. It also sets transit rules and guidelines, specifying the minimum maintenance requirements for rail cars and tracks. The FTA regulates through an oversight function that ensures state agencies adhere to federal regulations.

The DOT establishes bus safety requirements, including driver qualifications, training and testing. State transportation departments can impose additional laws and regulations like compulsory seat belts, vehicle size, vehicle weight and emergency exits.

The CMVSA, created in 1986, requires commercial vehicle drivers to obtain a commercial driver's license. Various states also have additional licensing requirements. Urban bus and train drivers are subject to drug, alcohol and substance abuse testing, both before employment and on a random basis, under the Drug-Free Workplace Act of 1988.

The ADA requires all new buses and rail vehicles used on urban transit routes to provide adequate accessibility, including wheelchair lifts for disabled people. By October 2006, half of a company's fixed-route vehicles had to be fitted with wheelchair lifts; by October 2012, all buses were required to be equipped with wheelchair lifts.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New entrants must adhere to numerous federal, state and local regulations, including obtaining permits and licenses and complying with environmental regulations.
Starting up for new companies can be costly as it requires significant investments in vehicles, equipment, insurance, fuel, maintenance and other operating costs.
Low product differentiation and overall services create a challenging landscape for new companies to compete with established operators with established brand recognition and reputation.

The public transport industry is capital-intensive, requiring substantial investment in infrastructure, vehicles, and technology. Maintenance and depreciation expenses are particularly elevated because equipment deteriorates with time and operations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Technological improvements increase the useful life of assets
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Technological improvements increase the useful life of assets, providing newly rolled-out public vehicles with lower depreciation costs. Still, public transportation's depreciation expense remains relatively stable as phasing out older infrastructure occurs gradually.

Worker unionization resulted in wage costs remaining relatively stable and consistently accounting for the largest expense in the industry, even while being offset by efficiency gains and improved technology.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Government Assistance Programs Boost Profit Amid Fuel Volatility
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Fare revenue covers nearly one-third of total operating expenses, while the remaining revenue is attributed to other sources, including advertising and debt financing. The industry would not be profitable without government assistance, which accounts for an estimated 60.0% of total operating expenses.

Unexpected changes in operational costs or reductions in government funding. Supply chain issues and volatility in the energy markets, which caused fuel prices to skyrocket, pressured profit. Public transportation is still recovering to get back to its pre-pandemic profit level.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The public transport industry is capital-intensive, requiring substantial investment in infrastructure, vehicles, and technology. Maintenance and depreciation expenses are particularly elevated because equipment deteriorates with time and operations.

volatility_points.volatility_title: COVID-19 RESTRICTIONS RESULTED IN PLUMMETING REVENUE
volatility_points.volatility_description: Consumers opted to social distance or use alternative methods of transport that didn't require contact with other commuters. Health concerns and travel restrictions plummeted ridership, leading to declining revenue for public transportation companies.

volatility_points.volatility_title: GOVERNMENT GRANTS PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION
volatility_points.volatility_description: The public transportation industry is heavily subsidized by government funding, which helps reduce revenue volatility. Funding packages usually don't fluctuate year to year in normal economic conditions.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Affordability and Ease of Use Boosts Revenue in Urban Areas
volatility_points.volatility_description: Public transportation is essential to providing affordable and accessible commuting options, particularly for those living in highly congested urban areas. Many large cities make owning a vehicle unpractical, pushing residents to rely on public transport.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technological development, including the creation of mobile apps that let customers book and pay for trips and monitor their bus or train's location in real-time, provides an opportunity for public transportation.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: DEPLOYMENT OF SAFETY AND EFFICIENCY SYSTEMS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies use GPS tracking systems to help prevent drivers from getting lost and provide live updates on trip progress to a website so consumers can check the expected arrival time. Many vehicles are equipped with "panic buttons," which a driver can press in case of passenger illness, motor accidents or other emergencies, further improving the safety standards of public transportation.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by changing trends in tourism?
FAQs.answer: While most revenue is generated through commuters traveling to work or school, tourism also plays a role. Any large changes in tourism may have a similar effect on industry performance.

FAQs.question: How has discretionary spending affected your major consumers?
FAQs.answer: Increasing discretionary spending is generally harmful to the industry. When people have more money to spend, private transportation modes, including personal vehicles and taxi ridership, increase. This decreases demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: Is your operation located in an area with a high number of potential customers?
FAQs.answer: Cities with large populations are generally the largest operators of industry organizations. For example, New York City is the largest city in the country and operates the largest transportation organization.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile crude oil prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Oil prices are important for many industry operators, especially those that operate buses. Furthermore, a change in oil prices may affect the price of private transportation, including taxis, which would have an effect on the industry.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Autonomous technology is not used on a wide scale in the United States, though select systems do use this technology. For example, the Newark International Airport monorail operates without a human at the controls.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, such as 3D printing, Internet of Things (IoT) and autonomous vehicle usage in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Operators are leveraging new technology to create better, safer rides. For example, rail-signal technology is being used to improve safety, while traffic-signal technology implemented to increase bus speeds.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Trade organizations are not extremely important in this industry, given the relationship between operators and the government. For example, in New York City's MTA, state and local governments play a role in who works on the agency's board.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Given the relationship between governments and agencies, whereby the government provides large subsidies, industry operators generally adhere to energy-efficient regulations.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Since this industry is consumer-facing, customers must pay for services before boarding. As a result, the industry does not have challenges with customers paying on time.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins are generally low or negative. The nation's largest system, New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, routinely operates at a loss.

FAQs.question: How loyal is your customer base? How do you ensure repeat customers? What percentage of revenue is devoted to retaining customers?
FAQs.answer: The customer base is very loyal when it comes to public transportation as it is cheaper compared to owning a car and using a cab every day. To ensure repeat customers, weekly, monthly and sometimes yearly passes are sold, which are cheaper compared to single rides.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in government regulations? Have you had any issues with government regulations in the past?
FAQs.answer: Public transit authorities must comply with federal, state and local licensing, safety, financing and regulatory requirements. Regulations in this industry are mainly related to safety, so there have been very few incidents in which issues have been raised with government agencies.

FAQs.question: Are you located in a densely populated area? Would you say that your business is located in a "good" location? Easy access for clients
FAQs.answer: Urban transit systems that have rail terminals and bus stops in convenient locations, along with well-scheduled services, are able to attract more customers. Businesses located in "good" locations attract residential and commercial riders.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor unemployment rates to plan your business accordingly? How has low unemployment benefited your business in the past?
FAQs.answer: The total US workforce is an important indicator of industry demand, as the majority of public transit systems are used primarily by commuters. A low unemployment rate leads to more people using public transportation to reach their workplaces.

FAQs.question: How much do you rely on federal funding? How do you plan to mitigate this threat?
FAQs.answer: Federal, state and local governments are important sources of public transit funding because the majority of operations are largely subsidized by taxes and grants. By increasing revenue generated through single-trip riders, the threat from federal funding can be reduced.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of urban population growth? How are you attracting more of this increased population to your services?
FAQs.answer: Urban population growth drives demand for urban transit systems, as most individuals in densely populated cities rely on public transportation. Developing new stations near urban populated areas, people can be attracted to use public transportation.
